description:
I love Gyudon.  I search high and low for good Gyudon for lunch.  When i think Japanese food I don't think sushi - I think Japanese Curry, Sukiyaki, Saba Shioyaki and Gyudon.

Tenmatsu has great Gyudon!  Paper thin, perfectly cooked sukiyaki beef with great sauce and onions.  Great great great Japanese Curry!  The perfect curry sauce and pieces of beef you can cut with a spoon.  The bento boxes are HUGE.

The place is probably 6x6 (maybe 9x9) it's tiny but don't let the small size fool you the food here is legit and very reasonable - Gydon $9 Japanese Beef Curry $9.

Tenmatsu get's crowded and finding the food in a crowd in a tiny space can be challenging.  There is a refrigerated section for sushi, a warming area for the rice bowls, a spot for the bento boxes and the ramen / udon / curry is served by one of the cashiers.  

Great lunch spot!
author: Dave K.

description:
TL;DR Okay food. Long line. 

Came in for lunch, and the Bento boxes were almost out just after 12pm, but they still had a good amount of sushi in back; the fridge had sushi, sashimi, and a poke bowl (which wasn't actually a poke bowl, just ahi tuna).

Got a small box of seared salmon for $6.50. It was labeled a salad but had just a couple tiny lettuce leaves. I did at least manage to get some ginger at the front which was a plus. 

At the end of the line near the register, they had hand rolls for $2.25/piece. Had I known, I would have just gotten a bunch of those, but the line was crazy and store was packed, so it would've been more trouble to try returning my salmon. Next time!
author: Nic Z.

description:
This is a great place for a quick grab and go meal (just like they mention). Everything is pre-made and is either heated (like the rice bowls) or cooled (like the sushi) and ready to eat. I just wanted something small so I got a spam masubi and two hand rolls. They were all pretty good and fairly priced.

Overall, everything was decent including the price and I would go back for a quick meal.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Sometimes you're in a rush and just want to grab something pre-made to go.  Sure, there are tons of places hawking salads and sandwiches, but that gets boring quickly.  This place reminds me of the convenience stores in Tokyo, with really tasty quick lunch options.

Spam Musubi: I have mixed feelings about this.  One hand, I thought the rice was really innovative since they seemed to mix scallions and spam bits to jazz it up.  On the other hand, the spam on top was a bit lackluster since it wasn't glazed and/or crispy, just out of the can.

Pork Belly Bento: I really really really liked this bento box.  The pork belly was way better than you'd expect at a grab-and-go bento joint.  The meat was firm yet tender while the fat on top was silky smooth; all encased in an inviting glaze.  The cabbage underneath was a great pairing.  Loved the little sausages as a side dish, since pork with pork always works.  And the red colored fried tofu squares were an extra bonus protein.  Loved that they were acting like a vegan impostor to the pork belly.
author: Adam B.

description: Got takeout from here which was OK.  The Oyako don which is chicken and egg over rice and the green tea and mango mochi
author: Sunil R.

description:
Tenmatsu is a strictly grab-and-go lunch spot in FiDi for Japanese bento boxes. It carries both hot and cold bento boxes. Hot boxes include chicken or fish with rice, tempura, shu mai, tofu in different combinations. Cold boxes include sushi and sashimi in various combinations. It also has some Japanese curry over rice and donburi bowls. 

Over a period of time I've tried a bunch of both their hot and cold options. The hot bento boxes are loaded and difficult to finish in one sitting even for a hearty eater like myself. Taste-wise also they are on point. Sushi and sashimi has always been fresh. Sashimi is not the melt in your mouth variety but it's good enough for the price.

Prices for most items are in the $13-$15 range which is very reasonable for the area and quality of food. Tenmatsu is my preferred choice for getting to-go Japanese food for lunch in and around FiDi.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
I had the tofu bowl and a side of green beans and unfortunately it wasn't all that good. I got the Kinoko Gohan with Chicken from meal pal which I put as a time of 2:15-2:30 but when I got there at around 2:15, the place had already started cleaning up and didn't have anymore of what I had reserved. So that's how I ended up with the tofu and green beans.

The tofu was disappointing. It tasted like hot and sour soup mixed with tofu, which while could be good in some instances, didn't taste too good because there was so much rice and cabbage on the bottom. In all the bowl contained too much veggies and plain rice and not enough sauce or tofu. The green beans though were not too bad, they were rather tasty and had a nice dash of peanuts on top combined with a nice sauce.

Overall, I would probably pass on choosing this place in the future, though it is possible that their meat items taste a lot better. The other items could taste better, so I might give it another chance.
author: Tyler T.

description:
I worked in the area for about 4 years now and honestly had never noticed this place until I got on Mealpal and this was one of the options. Selected the salmon rice bowl for lunch and came at 12:30 to pick up. I got to the counter and the chef had just walked out of the kitchen to put the bowls down so my bowl was piping hot. There was a piece of salmon with a bunch of cooked cabbage and a couple pieces of tofu skin on top of Japanese rice (my favorite). They have extra teriyaki sauce and tonkatsu sauce on a tray which I found super awesome and convenient especially since I love to slather my rice in teriyaki sauce.

Taste wise, the salmon was slightly overcooked but honestly, I drenched it in so much teriyaki sauce it didn't really matter. The rice was a little stuck together, but not hard. The tofu skin was a little salty. Overall, I really enjoyed my meal and would look forward to trying more things they offer.
author: Judy H.

description:
Came here on a weekday for lunch around 1pm. 

Food: Food here is all grab and go or pre made so it's tough if you're picky like me. I was going to get some pre boxed sushi but I changed my mind and got the veggie curry rice bowl. I only like certain types of nigiri and it didn't specify what was in each box so I didn't want to risk not liking it. The veggie curry bowl was alright, a little bit heavy on the sauce though. 

Service: the line was pretty long when I was here, but it went quickly since most people just grab and go. 

Ambiance: this is a small place to specifically take out your food. No seating area at all so plan on bringing your food out with you.
author: Hayley D.

description:
This is a convenient spot for a grab and go lunch if you are in the mood for Japanese. I have walked past this place dozens of times but always overlooked it. Finally decided to give it a try and it was what I expected -- far from mind-blowing but decent enough that I would come back. 

I have tried their sushi combinations which are usually around $14. The fish is alright, typical of what you would expect for pre-made sushi/sashimi platter. This is definitely not melt-in-your-mouth sashimi but it will probably satisfy a craving. Most recently tried their chicken katsu bento box ($13), and I felt the same way about it. I would pass on the spam masubi -- rice to spam ratio was disappointing and overall nothing special.

What drew me in initially was the mochi pics I saw on Yelp! I inquired of the cashier and was sad to find out that the owner hurt her arm and is temporarily not making mochi. Happy to hear that all mochis are handmade so definitely will be asking about it on my next visits until I get to try it :)
author: Mandi H.

description:
Picked up lunch with coworkers after our morning meeting today-- verdict is that the fish is definitely fresh (yay!) and sashimi cuts are above average in size (another yay!), but is short of 4 stars in a couple ways: 1) doesn't taste strongly of the respective fish's flavor, and 2) is not buttery / doesn't dissolve in your mouth like super premium fish. All things considered, still a solid spot for lunch in FiDi.

I got the sashimi and a spam musubi.

Sashimi came with 2 slices each of: 1) salmon-- not bad, but not the buttery umami-ness that is other restaurants' salmon sashimi, 2) yellowtail-- not super fresh, but not bad either, slightly lemony, 3) tuna-- not bad, meat kind of lingers in your mouth and doesn't dissolve, 4) red snapper-- not too much taste on its own, doesn't dissolve.

Spam musbi-- rice is slightly hard (pre-made, I guess), but combo of egg, green onion pieces, and bits of spam make this a nice, snackable treat. 

Others at my office swear by this place though (as in there's a guy who will grab lunch from here every. single. day.). I've seen all the other dishes and I can't wait to try that beef donburi and their hand roll choices!
author: Nicole H.

description:
This place is very convenient for grab n go lunch. You can easily see all your options and grab what looks most appealing to you.

Reason for average score is because of the lack of efficiency in the shop. It gets so busy and chaotic during the lunch rush. There's people everywhere and no clear indication which line they are in (ordering food, cash payment, or credit/debit payment). All three "lines" are in the same vicinity in the front of the shop and it's super crowded and confusing. It doesn't help that the main female worker is running around spastically all through out the restaurant. 

Sushi is okay. Place is convenient and prices are standard for sushi.
author: S. S.

description:
Is this spot perfect?  No.  But their sushi is fresh and fairly high-quality, especially for a grab-and-go spot, prices are fair, and the food is always consistent.  With respect to their sushi, I've never had a bad piece of fish and the rice is very well cooked (I'm a stickler for good sushi rice.) The hand rolls here are great, if you need a little extra food, and options change daily.   I also really like their Chicken Udon, which is one of the few items that are made to order.  The noodles are cooked perfectly, the chicken is good, and the broth is well seasoned without being too salty.  

I also have a soft spot for Tenmatsu because it reminds me of locations in Tokyo where you can quickly grab a very good lunch to go.  Is this the fanciest Japanese restaurant in the city, not by a long shot - but I respect restaurants that serve good, consistent food, with friendly service, and don't try to over reach.  If you're in FiDi for lunch and you're looking for a spot that will scratch your itch for sushi / Japanese food without breaking the bank, this is the place.
author: Tom G.

description:
Great, casual Japanese food at a really good price.
I bought a fantastic 3 piece sushi set for only $5, while the same could cost $10 at a local grocery store. The only downsides were the limited options and somewhat slow service. The only cashier who was able to work the card mashing went out for a minute so I had to wait. Otherwise, I can't wait to go back and try the udon next time!
author: Miles M.

description:
A great place to get delicious hot Japanese dishes like donburi, sushi, bento boxes and mochi. Super quick and courteous service. A bit pricey but really fresh, high quality food. Veggie options are abundant and the veggie croquette is amazing and flavorful. I also love the cold ramen when the weather is right. They have a very good although expensive fresh mochi. 

Tasty options:
Beef Donburi
Oyako Don (Chicken and Egg)
Ribeye Steak Teriyaki
Green Tea and Raspberry Mochi
Sushi box selections look fresh and appealing

Delicious food and excellent service! The warm grab & go section is full of pleasant surprises. If you don't see what you want available in the grab & go heaters, you can just tell a waiter and the kitchen will prepare your lunch box right away. You can also order Japanese Curry at the counter. 

Whenever you are craving Japanese in FiDi come here and you won't be disappointed!
author: Maria M.

description:
Favorite takeout place.
Especially love those Donburi bowls, 5 stars.
Onigiri also good, 4.5 stars.
Currys good also, 4.5 stars. Wish there could be tofu options together with veggies.
Haven't tried those good looking sushi yet.
Udon just okay, 3 stars.
Service 5 stars.

Overall 5 stars.
author: Wangshu S.

description: I'm sad to have to down-grade this place as it was one of my favorites. However, the quality of the fish has seriously tanked (sorry for the bad pun), e.g. obviously frozen, thawed and re-frozen tuna lending itself to a mushy quality. The sushi rice was definitely sub-par too. I think I'll have to try another place.
author: Mi M.

description:
FOOD: Best traditional sushi you can grab and go for lunch in the area. I love the sushi combo #2 ($14)! Come before 12pm to beat the lunch rush and have the best selection. Nothing here has ever disappointed--the hot dishes are great, miso portions generous, sushi combos delicious, and selection of fridge teas great! There are hot and cold options. I LOVE that the green salad is packed with mixed greens, avocado, and flavor and is so inexpensive for downtown (I want to say $5). Makes getting your 5 a day that much easier :). 

SERVICE: Everyone is super friendly! You can make edits to hot food orders (e.g., add broccoli to udon). FYI for anyone reading that you can pay for grab-and-go hot/cold case food up front immediately. Center station in front of kitchen is for ordering hot/specialty food (i.e., miso, udon, hand rolls). 

AMBIANCE: No seating, just grab and go.
author: Helen W.

description:
Great staple in FiDi for grab-n-go sushi, donburi, rice balls, and bento boxes prepped for you, or noodle soups made to order! It's an awesome option in FiDi for those who can't take a long lunch break but want something of decent restaurant quality without the wait. They seem to have a good selection early in the lunch hour, but around 1:30-2PM most of the food is gone. Come as early as you can for the best stuff!

I haven't tried any of their sushi platters yet (but they look promising and I heard their fish is fresh!), but I've tried their Ume rice ball (plum), their salmon skin hand roll, and their made-to-order soba noodles. The rolls and rice ball were good, and the soba noodles were actually pretty good. For $8.50 they come with the soup base, egg and seaweed and for a few bucks extra you can add tofu, chicken, beef, etc. They offer other noodle options like udon and ramen which may be something I'll try next as well as the sushi rolls and bento boxes! My coworker got their katsu donburi and thought it was good but probably needed more sauce.

All in all, it gets the job done for lunch :)
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Got some salmon sushi, and found 3 plastic shards in it! I thought it was fish bone at first but it wasn't. I bent them and they flexed all the way... Bones will break eventually. 

Luckily I'm a slow eater, so I didn't accidentally swallow them. 

Plastic (and anything, even bones) are never supposed to be in sushi. This was my first time here... Loved the idea of an easy quick sushi grab-and-go place, but this makes me reconsider coming back. Quality control needs to be enforced.
author: Evelyn M.

description:
Sometimes I need a touch of the motherland to get me through a long work day, or at least that's what I try to convince myself to justify the carb overload that I know can't be good for me from a donburi bowl. What happens is I think about that scene in Ozu's "Tokyo Story" where poor widowed Noriko is sitting in her tenement studio, and since she doesn't have a real kitchen, she has to order donburi bowls that get delivered to her by messenger to entertain her aged in-laws. That scene actually predates Grubhub and Seamless by over sixty years.

Anyway, a hearty donburi bowl to someone like me who was raised by a transplanted Japanese mother is just like a plate of biscuits and gravy to Jamie W. Comfort food that stays in your subconscious and eventually needs to be fed to your belly. They have one here, the $9.50 Oyako Don, which consists of chicken, scrambled egg, onions and mushrooms all simmered together and put over rice to steam (photo: http://bit.ly/1zflAVw). The term 'oyako don' actually means 'parent-child rice bowl' because chicken and egg exist in the same bowl.

Usually the combo freaks me out because of the genocidal implications, but I make exception for this one dish since it can be tasty. I just wish this one wasn't overwhelmed by the amount of rice underneath. I added insult to injury by ordering a $2.50 Spam Musubi (photo: http://bit.ly/1yIbmuO). Yes, you heard me. Spam on rice wrapped in nori. Actually Spam reminds me of my dad since he was raised in Hawaii and the one dish he cooked when I was a child was Spam fried rice. Anyhow, you take the food to go in one of their reusable bags since it's a mere closet in here.

FOOD - 3 stars...evokes warm memories but the execution could be better
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...this is a Ginza-size operation so not enough for me to comment
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...always pretty courteous in here
TOTAL - 3 stars...have you seen my childhood?
author: Ed U.

description:
Tenmatsu is a quick, grab-and-go (Chinese owned?) lunch bento place on the outskirts of Chinatown. 2 stars seems a tad harsh but based on the beef stew donburi I had - filling but mediocre - "Meh. I've experienced better" is a perfect description.

Kudos for having a large menu and accepting credit cards; if I ever returned to the area for another week-long training, I would be open to going back and trying other things on the menu...
author: Steve L.

description:
Totally regret that I gave this place a try......
Got Buta Don takeout for lunch which is supposed to have sliced pork meat, tofu skin, mushroom, onion, and cabbage with rice. But I was shocked when I got back to my office and opened it up..... There are 3 slices of pork, 2 tiny pieces of tofu skin, and probably 2-3 slices of mushroom and that's it! I got a whole bowl of onions and cabbages! ISN'T THAT GREAT?! Yummmm......
author: Christina J.

description: Tenmatsu is the to-go sushi lunch spot of choice for me and my colleagues. Reasonably priced bento boxes with delicious sushi. If they're out of the sushi box that you're looking for, the staff doesn't mind if you push back the curtain and make a request of the sushi chefs.
author: Connor C.

description: I thought Tenmatsu stopped making spam masubis because the last several times I have gone, they didn't have them.  Turns out they just make a very limited number, so they sell out by noon just about every day.  They are leaps and bounds better than you have ever had. I honestly hate to recommend them because they sell out so quickly every day and I want them for myself, but I gotta be honest, they are phenomenal.  Went in at 11:00AM today and got one as well as an order of miso soup and let me tell you - the miso soup is the best I have ever had BY FAR.  One masubi and one soup was $5 - which is a great price for lunch in the fidi.  The sushi here is pretty pricey, but it is always fresh and good.  You shouldn't miss this miso soup and this spam masubi, but if you do I won't be mad because I'm selfish like that.
author: Emma H.

description:
I normally think this place has decent sushi, but today i found a bone in my eel roll. I know bones are natural, but this clearly shows careless food practices in preparing the fish properly. I wouldn't be as upset if it wasn't so overpriced. I expect at the very least quality for high prices. I'd also like to state that their health inspection scores have continuously dropped over the years. In their last health inspection in March of this year they were cited for improper cooling methods, which has to be one of the most critical aspects of handling raw fish. 
To sum up: overpriced, lacks quality, questionable food practices.
author: Nicole H.

description:
For the type of eatery it is (grab-n-go Japanese food), Tenmatsu does the job well. 

They offer a wide array of Japanese foods that are ready to be eaten quickly, from donburis topped with karaage and pork to sushi plates and udon. For the area, they're all priced in the range I was expecting. 

My review is for the sushi and sashimi plate ($13.50). Overall, it's quite serviceable. All the cuts of fish were fresh, and in the plate I had, my favorite one of all was the eel roll. It is pricier than if you were to go to 7-11, but if you want to absolutely ensure that you will not get some type of stomach ailment, stop by a place like Tenmatsu. 

3 stars, only because it does the job well, but not awe-inspiring.
author: Viet N.

description: Yum! Definitely a go to place for a quick sushi lunch in FiDi. Tenmatsu is mostly grab-and-go, but since I eat early, it's *basically* prepared to order. The sushi rolls are fresh and satisfy my sushi cravings! That said, they are pricey at $14/roll. The handrolls and bento bowls are more reasonably priced.
author: Connie Q.

description: I got their basic teriyaki bowl and it was extremely salty, which made it difficult to eat. The chicken was good but the rest was overly saturated with salt.
author: Becca Y.

description:
I love their Bento boxes! Very tasty and very filling. Especially their fried fish and tonkatsu ones. But my favorite thing of all... their Strawberry Mochi.

I am taking a great risk by calling that out, but it the best strawberry mochi I have ever had. Hopefully after saying that, I will still be able to get some, because a limited quantity are made fresh that day and I usually get there just in time to grab the last one. Its GIGANTIC with a HUGE, MOIST, Strawberry smack in the center. Once you get to it, its like heaven is EXPLODING JUICES in your mouth.

I'm a fan.
author: Bryan M.

description: Always a good selection of food, bento boxes and sushi Togo boxes. Good selection, they also serve hand rolls and salads for a healthier alternative.  Make sure to check out the wall because it's also a menu for other items. Could easily be overlooked as just design writing on the walls. Overall quick fast sushi with the quality you can expect. Make sure to come early, gets really crowded right at 12pm lunchtime rush.
author: Mark D.

description:
Tasty, quick spot to grab food and run to your next meeting. Everything I've had there is delicious, but I prefer their beef entrees over the chicken or salmon. ;) Tiny place, so you kinda have to make up your mind before someone reaches over and grabs the last item you were JUST about to grab.
It's one of my local-to-the-office favorite spots.
author: Cindy D.

description:
Quick grab and go with a nice variety of bento boxes. They have a little refrigerator that is continuously refilled with the bento boxes as soon as new ones are ready, so the food is quite fresh.

The place however is tiny which makes it really hard to pick out your food and wait in line especially during the lunch rush. I also find the quantity of rice to be significantly more than the quantity of meat provided which makes it a little hard to eat. 

The line does move quickly but if you're in a rush they do have a separate line for cash only.
author: Zoher Z.

description: This is a convenient place for a grab and go. I enjoyed the variety of bento boxes and rice bowls that they have. However, it is definitely a hit or miss. There are times when my food is great but I also notice how there are times when my food tasted like it's 1 week old. It could partially be my fault as I could choose any other bowls or bento boxes, but I would also assume that everything should be equally fresh. I give it a 3 star still since it's delicious when it's fresh and reasonably priced for lunch in FiDi.
author: Annie X.

description:
Only fresh sushi you'll get in the area and it's all TO-GO! 

This is a perfect place to get something quick and delicious! I bought the poke and salmon roll and both had FRESH RAW FISH! I love it! :) The poke is a bit spicy but spicy in all the right way! The salmon roll had more fish inside the roll, it wasn't just packed with imitation crab or tempura. They also sell a variety of rice dishes and donburi bowls. It seems like the hand rolls are really popular as well and there's about 5 different kinds! Some of them are pre-made and sold in the front. 

What I love the most is the little japanese man that takes care of the orders! He is so adorable and always smiling when speaking to customers! He really makes this little to-go place feel like an authentic japanese place!
author: Sabrina L.

description:
For everyone else who takes late lunches too, you HAVE to go here at 2pm...everything is 20% off! Your best bet is getting there around 1:45 and hovering until he puts out the discount sign. They will literally close up shop whenever they sell out so get ready for heartbreak if you get there too late.

The bentos and side dishes are all amazing. I was so surprised to find that the vegetarian bento is actually my favorite. Everything is so flavorful and fresh! Have yet to try the sushi items.

The small Japanese man is the cutest.
author: Debra L.

description:
I really dig this place!! A coworker brought us here because it was a quick option to grab some quick lunch before heading back to the office. Tenmatsu basically serves up almost all types of Japanese meals that you could possibly crave. From the bentos to the dons to the sahimi slices to even the mochis (which I have yet to try), the food options here are wide and varied, and best of all, FAST. That's all people in FiDi care about during lunch anyways.

I got the oyako-don which is just chicken and egg and a spam musubi. The spam musubi was on point since they seasoned the rice really well. I was actually pretty disappointed with the oyako-don mostly because the chicken was a bit dry and not very flavorful, though there definitely was a ton of it so it ended up being pretty filling because the bed of rice is also gigantic. My con is that it wasn't that flavorful and was actually pretty plain so I ended up just dumping soy sauce on it.

In the future, I'd probably want to try the albacore tataki cuts since those looked pretty good and maybe pair it with the spam musubi? There are definitely so many promising options plus the added bonus of speed make this place very attractive.

Also, if you check in on Yelp, you get 10% off! 

tldr; fast japanese food that is pretty decent
author: Jasmine X.

description:
I get it, it's the financial district - grab-and-go, fast, expensive - it's what to expect.

This place is the epitome of to-go, expensive, and fast food. I got the chirashi bowl, $13.50. Actually for chirashi, that's not bad at all. I thought the quality was very good for to-go sushi. The chirashi came with salmon and ahi sashimi over rice and seaweed. It was a nice lunch. The portion was filling and at the end of the day, I wasn't too mad that I spent that much on a to-go bowl of sushi.

This place is a grab-and-go place. The other options they have are similar - bento bowls/boxes, which go for around $9, and other sushi bentos, all around $10-13. I think the chirashi is the best thing they have to offer in terms of quality. The bentos look pretty good and the sushi bentos look good too, although I don't feel like I would be okay with spending as much on those.

What is surprising about this place is the quality of sushi and fish. It's pretty high for the financial district, for the price, and for the fact that it is a grab-and-go sushi place. I don't think there is a comparable grab-and-go sushi place around. So I can say with confidence that this will be my place for affordable sushi until something better pops up!
author: Junel S.

description:
This place is cheap with the amount of food you receive. They have a variety of bento boxes, udon, rice bowls, and mochi. 

Whenever I'm feeling Japanese I always drop by here since the service is quick and everyone is very friendly, the food is delicious as well.
author: Dorris W.

description: This place is so amazing. The first time I went in, I was in heaven. There is so much variety! I have to grab a quick lunch because I'm at school, and there are bentos and all kinds of sushi rolls already prepared and super fast to take out. Even though it's all packaged, it's so fresh! I love this place. I'm going to be there all the time.
author: Madeleine M.

description: For a quick, efficient, Japanese pick-up place, this place is AMAZING! They have a ton of menu items, the staff are so friendly and nice. Everything is so neatly organized and you can tell they take pride in their food and service. Highly recommend!
author: cassy f.

description: Great place for a quick grab-and-go lunch in the FiDi area. They have a variety of pre-made sushi, bentos, rice bowls, curry, salads, and noodle bowls. The Japanese man who works here is a gem. He is very welcoming and always willing to assist you with anything. If you don't see what you want on the shelves ready-made, ask him and he will make one for you. I'm knocking off two stars because it it's a little expensive, and the quality of their hot food items could be better.
author: Hana K.

description:
I seldom write bad reviews, but my recent experience at Tenmatsu leaves me appalled and thoroughly disappointed with their handling of an egregious, and unforgivable situation.

I must preface this statement by stating that I have over 20 years experience in the restaurant business, and have my food handling certificate, issued by the City of San Francisco.

Recently,while basking in the glorious sunshine of San Francisco, I happened across the Tenmatus sushi outlet.

I passed by a sushi restaurant on Pine and I decided to shop nearby to compare the offerings. 

It was a hot day, above 90 degrees, as I stepped inside the Tenmatsu doorway and took notice of the 12 or so bento boxes inches away from the opened doors.
Noodles, rice, salads and sashimi were offered, at a 20% discount; wow! 
The sashimi boxes were the closest to the door, and as the day was hot, seemed suspiciously ill placed, given the temperature inside and outside the restaurant.

 I asked the chef who was arranging the boxes and assisting the other customer about which types of fish were included in the box, and how long they had been outside of the refrigerator, now barren, and 10 feet to his rear. I had spent at least 5 minutes gazing at the menu and at their offerings.

The chef was an elderly Japanese man, about 4'4", and had a bandana wrapped around his head which suggested he was a sushi chef, but I couldn't be sure. The man dismissively replied that the sashimi was , "fresh", and that I , "don't worry about how long it was out" and scurried to tidy up the table and the offerings.

His English was quite good. I asked him how long the sashimi had been out in the 90 degree heat, and if the lack of refrigeration would have rendered the sashimi inedible?
I touched the box, and it felt quite warm, as it was slowly heating up in the ambient temperature of 90 degree. He smiled as he looked at me, but did not answer.  I informed him that it would not be sanitary to serve such raw fish to the public, and if someone were to consume it, they would become sick.
 
I asked him if it was normal for Tenmatsu to leave raw fish out from the refrigerator for extended periods of time, and if he had a Food handling certificate. I indicated that it would probably be in the best interest of the public health, and the restaurant to avoid serving sashimi that had been
out of refrigeration for extended periods of time, especially on days where the temperature outdoors was in excess of 90 degrees.

The Japanese chef looked at me directly and said to me, in perfect English, while  smirking, " leave this restaurant, and do not come back. You do not need this food, and I do not care what you think about this sashimi. Go, get out now", he said forcefully.

I was appalled. Really? 

I spoke to him  in a sincere way, and did not deserve the disrespect and contempt he showed me. The irony of the situation was that behind him on the wall, there was some poetry in chalk espousing "compassion and loving attention to the food " served there, according to a Japanese tradition. 

I suffer no fools, and sought out a manager nearby. I stood outside, shocked and dismayed by the rudeness of this crotchety curmudgeon. This rudeness was unacceptable and completely unwarranted.

I have never been so rudely treated by an employee in all of my life. I did not feel welcomed by that man, and he took  pleasure at mistreating the customer.

A Chinese store manager, Jennifer, came out, profusely apologized, but when asked why she would allow anyone to behave so miserably towards a customer, she offered two very 
lame excuses, " his English is not so good" and " the hot weather must have made him short tempered". Excuse me, Jennifer, but mistreatment of customers is never allowed, nor is excusable, Jennifer.

Why employ such a dullard, even if he was the Japanese face of a Chinese owned sushi restaurant? I do not care which nationality makes my food, as long as it is prepared well, and fresh. Quality doesn't depend on nationality, in my book.

She asked the bandana wearing louse to apologize. He smiled the saccharin smile and without making eye contact with me, and under his breath said, "sorry" AS HE TURNED AWAY and scampered back to the kitchen. I was shocked. Jennifer ran back to the kitchen and tried to have the chef return to apologize. He went with the , " my English is not so good" excuse, which when spoken in perfect English, like the hot sashimi, wasn't passing the smell test.

We were dealing with a 5 year old Japanese elder, apparently. I felt sorry that the manager had this louse on her payroll. Tenmatsu must never allow such disgusting displays of contempt for customers to permeate their business if they want to succeed in The City.

Tenmatsu can learn an important lesson in health codes and disciplining their staff, courtesy of the angry Japanese dwarf.

Put on your listening ears, Willy NelsonSan, you are about to get an education:

DON'T BE RUDE. EVER.
author: Jersey K.

description:
Good place for a quick grab-and-go lunch. They have a variety of pre-made bentos, rice bowls, noodle bowls, sushi and salad. I think most bentos and bowls are $10-13, so it's a little pricey, but everything looks pretty good!

I got a SASHIMI SALAD for $8.50. You're probably judging me.. who goes to a Japanese place and gets salad?! Apparently I do. The salad was just basic greens, but the sashimi was surprisingly fresher than I expected for a to-go place. I also liked the dressing that came with the salad. It had a LOT of wasabi in it, but it added a lot of flavor to the salad/sashimi. I'm glad I don't normally add much dressing to my salads otherwise I would've been crying all day.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Udon, miso soup, daily hand rolls, spam musubi, bento boxes, nigiri, donburi ... what does Tenmatsu NOT carry? It's a FiDi lunch dream come true and I've got fish cakes dancing in my head. 

The food is arranged with small bites (rice balls and spam musubi) on the right; hot rice, meat and veggie dishes in a warmed shelving unit; followed by fresh sushi, sashimi, tofu and salads in a chilled case. Their bentos are on the pricier side but you can mix & match a la carte with a salmon skin hand roll here, a miso soup there, add a side of kimchi and come out under $10 easy. The staff here is always super friendly and for dishes that are prepared upon order, they take great care in their presentation. There's one adorable older gent who's always brimming with enthusiasm when he puts together a miso soup order or cheerfully pointing out all of the daily specials as he rattles of each and every ingredient. 

If you have cash, there's a separate line that'll move you through more quickly. Grab a cold green tea out of the fridge and be on your merry way!
author: Faith Y.

description:
I'm rounding up from 3.5 stars. Generally, I'm a fan of these small, efficient "restaurants" (in quotation marks because it's just a takeaway place with ready-made items) and it adds more variety to the standard lunch spots. 

Pros:
- Lots of selection from donburi to bento boxes to tuna poke salad to spam musubi to hand rolls. Something for everybody!

Cons:
- On the pricey side. My chicken katsu bento box was $12.50 which seems a tad bit expensive.
- The food is above average - not awesome but pretty solid for lunch.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I think the lucky penny I found yesterday really aligned the stars and brought me to this gem.

While I do love being wined-and-dined at this city's finest sushi establishments, sitting across from a tall, dark, and stunningly handsome man, let me be honest and remember that happens less than ever.

So, when I want sushi (i.e. always), I gotta ride solo and keep it real with my debit card. Cue Tenmatsu. 

Here's how it went down:

I'm walking up Kearny and see sushi. Pause #1.
I take a step back and see 'to-go sushi'. Pause #2. (Really, I'm thinking, this place could be really bad, or, really good). 

I decided to go in, obviously. I'm an optimist. And, optimism wins, people. 

1. It's quick. In and out in 3 minutes. Win. 
2. It's FRESH. I was slightly shocked at this fact. No chewy sushi. Double win.
3. The combos were awesome. I got a 6-piece eel roll AND 5 pieces of Nigiri (salmon, tuna, yellowtail mix) for ONLY $13.50. Does this need further explanation?
4. The sweet little man who worked at the checkout asked how my day was going. It's mighty swell now, sir.
author: Amanda U.

description:
Grab 'n Go form here is a pretty efficient way to get some sushi for a workday lunch. There's also a decent selection of bentos (katsu bento, teriyaki bento, the standard fare), rice balls, and what seems to be a noodle/curry kitchen combined in the establishment (never tried this last part).

I bought a bento for a weekday lunch and was pleasantly surprised by how it tasted.
author: Alexander L.

description:
Today was my first try at Tenmatsu after new ownership took over and although most of the menu items have remained the same, I was highly disappointed by the spicy tuna hand-roll that used to be my very favorite when I was craving rice!!!  It was literally half the size and had barely any fish in it!  See my pic!  Also, they used to use Ahi and now they use albacore, there was a serious taste difference!

I also had the chicken teriyaki bowl and it was just ho-hum.  The service is still as pleasant as it was before and there were a few things in the cold bin that I'll definitely be trying out.  Until then Tenmatsu!
author: Brandy B.

description:
Right place with deals and energetic man walking around assisting everyone.

I am especially addicted to the Chicken teriyaki here!
author: Kendra S.

description: This place is absurdly quick and one of the few spots where I can get gyuudon in the city. Their sushi and sashimi is also good. Spam musubi and onigiris for any rice ball lovers makes this place an all around crowd pleaser if you need a quick lunch fix in fi-di/soma. I've yet to try their bentos but they seem of similar quality to their other items.
author: Omar M.

description:
My coworker and I were strolling along to Ramen Underground when all of a sudden he stops in front of Tenmatsu and stands staring in silence for what seems to be about 45 seconds before he finally says he wants to see what's inside. Soo you can say Tenmatsu has an attractive storefront?

This place has all kinds of pre-made Japanese goodies and hot items for order that you can take to go (or well there aren't any seats here so you have to take it to go) such as:

- Sushi rolls
- Donburi
- Bento boxes
- Spam musubis
- Japanese salads
- Udon

My coworker (who is Japanese) says the chefs in the kitchen are Japanese so yay for authenticity. 

We were excited with all of the selections they offered and spent 20 minutes before deciding on the Chasu udon with egg drop soup ($1 extra for egg drop) and seaweed. Both items were good! You have to order the udon at the counter and it takes about 5 minutes to get.

We came back another time and got the Yanagawa (barbequed eel) donburi and the Sansai udon. The donburi was pretty good and sweet tasting. The udon came with the normal broth since I didn't ask for the egg drop soup and the normal broth was way too salty, so get the egg drop soup!

All in all, the food is good. Or good for quick grab and go type food. 

The service here is great and the girl working here is super cute!
author: Jeanie F.

description:
This is a walk in and grab food to go kind of place. There are no tables. It's small and usually crowded, but as everyone is taking things to go, you probably won't ever spend more than 10min in the store. 

They have your standard bento boxes and domburi, which are good, but my favorite thing to do is grab a bunch of small things like Hijiki salad, onigiri ($1.50 each) and spam musubi (about $2, I think). Although they sell out quickly, the korroke are also good.

They have a vegetarian bento box, and is decently vegetarian friendly. Other than the veggie bento box, you have a few veggie onigiri and veggie sushi rolls.
author: Mariko F.

description:
This little grab-and-go japanese place is really cute! My coworker told me about it yesterday and I couldn't wait to try it. I got the chashu udon. It came in a little plastic bowl, separated from the soup base all wrapped and ready. The soup base is a little like an instant ramen soup base with a little more thickness and the noodles were slippery and somewhat chewy. I honestly didn't have very high expectations for grab-and-go ramen/udon, but this is pretty good for what it is. 

I noticed they also have donburis and sushi all packed and ready as well. Get here early though because they sell out fast! I got there around 1pm and the place was pretty much empty. I definitely want to come back earlier next time and try their gyudon. I love gyudons! (beef over rice bowl) 

They take all cards except discover. cheers!
author: Annie Z.

description: No crazy line as it is overshadowed by some of the other spots in the area.  Great food, convenient and reasonably priced.  Got the sashimi salad and salmon skin hand roll.  Tasted pretty fresh and good.  Will be back.  Wonder how the curry is.
author: Vincent D.

description:
Used to go here before it changed owners/mgmt (f/k/a Ebisu). 

I believe that the quality of food post-change has either been about the same or improved. I think the variety of food has expanded. The only thing I wish is that the chirashi bowl is more like $11 instead of $13.50!

You also really can't beat the friendliness of the cute Japanese guy who mans the miso soup/hand roll station. I also highly recommend getting the hand rolls--these seem to be very good value.
author: Sam R.

description:
This is a grab and go Japanese place. I was pleasantly surprised at the variety they offered: katsu, bento boxes, donburis, rolls and sashimi. 
Everything looked pretty good and the prices wasn't too steep. If you want Japanese food on the go, this is the place!
author: Kristy K.

description:
They're linked to Ebisu, so you know the quality is up to snuff.  

We've tried the donburi, curry, temaki(california), udon, bento set, and musubi.  All tasted very good.  Though the donburi bowl may look small to some, it is pretty filling and packed tight with ingredients.  That is in my opinion the best bang for the buck.

The beef curry was decent--not mind-blowing, but it gets the job done.  The bento set I've found ends up leaving you with a lot of rice; it would have been nice to have a more balanced proportion of other ingredients in conjunction with the rice.  It's definitely worth a try, though.

The udon and curry dishes are prepared to order.  The others are pre-made and left heated for foods that are served hot, and for the sushi and salads, they are left cold.  The food here is fresh.  We like it more than Tokyo Express.
author: Stephen N.

description:
This is a tiny shop that offers grab-n-go lunches.  

They have a tasty assortment of donburi, udon and sushi combo platters for you choose from.  Then there's a curry station, just tell the curry gal/guy what meat you want and they scoop out a big helping into a to-go container.  I usually order the veggie style curry with brown rice.  Some days there are big black shitake mushrooms, which are usually my favorite.  

I've had the crab and jelly fish sushi handrolls before.  The jelly fish made my sushi taste weird.  I won't be eating that one again.  But if your in the mood for curry, this is a great place to get your curry-on.
author: Jenny T.

description: Very Japanesey - tons of take away bentos, bowls, curry, hot soba/udon, onigiri.  Veggie versions offered in all categories.  Awesome lunch spot with GF, V options.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Sushi Craving and short on time.  Tenmatsu is the place for you.  I was a little skeptical at first about to-go sushi but, was assured that San Fran does it right.  Where I'm from, sushi on the run is a couple California Rolls at the super market and it wouldn't be my first choice by any means.  To my surprise, Tenmatsu had quite a selection.  I wish some of the rolls were labeled better so I knew what I was getting into but, the young man helping out was more than willing to answer any questions I had.

I decided on a Bento Box with Mongolian beef and a Miso Soup.  The soup was great and very hearty compared to your typical broth, tofu, and scallions combo elsewhere.  The Bento Box, on the other hand, was pretty disappointing.  Because it's to-go, everything is cold and pretty much like eating leftovers.  On the upside we shared an order of Pork Gyoza that was fantastic.  

I would be back for the Miso and Gyoza.  I'm also interested in the noodle bowls.  I didn't realize they were there until I was checking out.  I think this place is worth another try but first impression was so so.
author: Scotty C.

description:
I'm a fan of the simplicity of the process -- you walk in, take a look at the menu (they have pictures placed around the small space) and you just grab what you want, pay, and go. I had no idea what to do when I first walked in, but there were a couple other people inside. If you walk a few feet forward when you walk in, along the right side there's a fridge with the sushi items. Along the opposite wall is the heated items in a heated area (bento boxes, etc.). I'm not sure that they placed everything in an intuitive place though. Your first thought would be go walk to the counter in front of you right? That's just where the desserts are. The register is behind you when you walk inside haha.

-Bento Box #2 -- like I said above, the hot food items are sitting in a heated area. The food isn't made to order, so it's not fresh. It doesn't make for the best fried fish or beef. I'm not going to recommend the hot food items. I'll probaby go for the sushi next time. Lesson learned.
-Since the hot food isn't made to order, I can't really justify spending $8 again on a bento box.

+Green tea mango mochi -- this was $3.50, but it's rather large. It's also one of the more complex mochis I've had. The outer layer is green tea, then there's red bean, and inside of that is mango! Yum!
+Simple, fast process and service
author: Katherine S.

description: Humongous box of veggie sushi. $10 for the win. Seriously huge. 6 pieces each of cucumber, pickled daikon, umeboshi, and avocado. Ready made and in the grab and go case. Definitely cheaper than any veggie sushi option nearby.
author: Daniele D.

description:
Long long ago, at the same location there existed a place called Ebisu. It too was a bento box store that sold almost exactly the same dishes and it was delicious. Fast forward to the present, we have Tenmatsu. I've given it a few tries but wasn't impressed. More disappointed if anything.

The first time I came, the place was closed during peak lunch hour. It was open the day before, and the days after. I thought maybe it was their day off, but even the hours posted said it should be open.

The next time I stopped by and looked at their hot lunches. Nothing seemed too appealing, but I settled for the Chicken Karrage Bowl. It looked pretty good with plenty of chicken. When I got back to my work and took a bite I was... well disappointed. The chicken pieces were more batter than chicken and it soaked up the salty teriyaki sauce. They gave me plenty of rice, but it was probably to balance out the salty chicken. A few weeks later, I just wanted a snack, so I decided to get one of their crab hand rolls supposedly made out of real crab. The crab pieces looked and tasted more like imitation crab.

The set up and dishes are practically the same as Ebisu before, but the flavors just aren't right. The staff are nice at the very least.
author: David C.

description:
This use to be one of my favorite lunch spots for work, but now it's just so mehhh. They changed chefs awhile back, but the items they produce continue to go downhill. 

I use to come here at least once a week, not i haven't gone in the last 3 months!!

So sad since it's hard to find good, reasonably priced food in FiDi.
author: Kristen C.

description:
Very tasty and quick lunch grab. The bentos are excellent, and the sushi is good. The oyakodon is my go-to. I usually get a croquette or a thing of gyoza with it.

The people who work there are super nice - once I accidentally dropped my gyoza and sauce went everywhere, and they just gave me a new one! Also has a 10% discount if you are there before noon (Yelp check-in offer), which is when you want to go anyway if you want to avoid long lines.

Took off a star because their bowls tend to have a bad meat to rice ratio, and you end up with half a bowl of plain white rice in the middle of your lunch.
author: Jiwon K.

description: Surprisingly legit Japanese bento's, though I hear it's not Japanese-owned. Guess it doesn't matter if they can produce quality food. I had a hamburg bento and it was great. It's a bit pricey, though...  I'd go back more often if their prices were a couple bucks cheaper.
author: Kazu O.

description:
Hamachi kama is delicious when they have it.

Sashimi salad is yummy.

Cold noodles is absolutely SALTY as sea water!

Salmon Bento box is once again SALTY.  

I love the service but most things are over salted here so I end up drinking way more water after a meal from Tenmatsu.
author: TM O.

description: Really convenient for Japanese grab and go food (rice bowls, sushi). A nice option for sushi that does not seem sketchy or really expensive. I've had a few different sushi boxes (rolls and sashimi), and they are on par with the quality of sushi from a good Japanese grocery store.
author: Hayley C.

description: Tenmatsu is an awesome sushi place for those busy FiDi workers who need to GaG (Grab and Go :P). The sushi is good quality and made daily. Unlike the "refrigerated sushi" at something like supermarkets, tenmatsu really only uses the refrigerators for show as all of the food I grab is still hot and not a bit cold at all! There is also a sweet 10% deal off anything before 12pm if you check in on yelp and I heard there are specials later on in the day near closing as well!
author: Wilson T.

description: This is a definite go-to for lunch, it even makes the walk to get there worth it.  The sushi / sashimi is fresh, the hand rolls are yummy and the man assisting always has a smile on his face.  For FIDI, the pricing is good too.
author: Cindy F.

description:
Been coming here when it was still Ebisu (yup I miss it, food was better), but this place is still good.  Cheap smaller sized handrolls (about $2~$3 each) and onigiri's (about $1.50~$2.00 each).  Curry is enough to feed 2 average people.

Plenty of options to choose from in this small little grab and go spot
Udon, Curry, Bento, Sushi, Donburi, Mochi, and more
Lots of Vegetarian items (I'm talking meat analogue)

Super friendly staff, highly recommended!

Food runs out quick, all the good stuff is gone before 1.
author: Anthony C.

description:
When this was the downtown grab-and-go location of Ebisu, I was never impressed. The sushi did not live up to the Sunset location.  This place is much better. Still not great for sushi, since it sits out. But it's great for things like teriyaki bowls. I don't think grab-and-go chicken teriyaki can be any better than this place.

I find the customers in there can be pretty rude though -- for example, hogging access to the warm fridge and not moving when you say excuse me, and a lot of line cutting.
author: Noah R.

description:
A great grab and go option if you're short on time for lunch.  Wide selection of sushi, bentos, rice bowls, and udon.  Sushi options are your best bet, as the rice bowls/bentos are a bit hit or miss.  Haven't tried the udon yet though.

Bonus for their friendly and helpful staff!
author: Cin S.

description: Shucks, i forgot to check in to yelp & get a discount even though I saw the offer a while back. Anyway, today was my first time here. The pre-made foods are to the right. I didn't see it originally when I walked in (i'm not the most observant person). I ended up getting some sushi for $13.50 and a strawberry mochi for $3.50. Wow, expensive lunch. The sushi was below average tasting and overpriced. I actually threw out about a third of it because it tasted like supermarket sushi. The mochi was huge but I've tasted better. It was nice to try something new though. The man who ran the cash register was really nice.
author: Wendy L.

description:
The grab and go stuff is all pretty good. But all I really care about is the curry.

Tenmatsu vs. Muracci's:

Tenmatsu:
- Cheaper (barely)
- Faster
- More veggies standard
- Better katsu

Muracci's:
- Spicier (with option to be much spicier)
- More meat options
- Better meat portions

You can't go wrong either way. If you want spicy, go to Muracci's. Otherwise, Tenmatsu is a great option.
author: Ben M.

description: Small and convenient the portions are very large for a price that's reasonable! Get there early because some things run out. But super great service and great food
author: Timothy T.

description: I always find something tasty in here for lunch. I usually get one of the sushi options, fish curry or hamachi special meal. My coworkers tend to say their food is too salty, but I think it's the meat items they get. I've never had any overly salty issues from the fish items. Prices really vary, as you can get a hand roll or rice ball for $1-$2 or a full meal for $10-$12. The sushi prices vary in size and can range from $7-$13. Always a good lunch spot to grab something quickly - highly recommend it if you haven't been yet.
author: Shira O.

description: Happened to stumble to this place on my way to Anthony's shoes next door and lucky me!!! What it felt like almost seeing the Virgin Mary, I see a table full of my favorite grab n go foods! Spam musubis, onigiri, mini hand rolls all under $2 each!!! Needless to say, I grabbed 8 of different flavored snacks and still had enough to grab a Hawaiian milk tea...all for less than an Andrew Jackson! Www.thebombdiggity.com   5/5 judo chops!
author: Dustin G.

description:
MOCHI MOCHI MOCHI!

Found this place once I moved up to San Francisco next to the office near Kearny and California Street. This place sells amazing Mochi. The highlight is definitely the Green Tea Mochi with White Bean and Mango. The Mochi is soft and the white bean complements the juicy ripe mango perfectly. 

Additionally, the restaurant offers a wide variety of Japanese classic food such as spam masubi, japanese cury, bento boxes, donburi bowls, and japanese salads!

Be sure to come here early before 12 as many of the items sell out by 1pm! 

Overall great food and service! Will always come back during lunches!
author: Stephen C.

description:
I love that this place is so close to my work. They have bento boxes, donduri, curry, rice balls, hand rolls, and more. Everything is pretty affordable too, considering it's the financial district. The hand rolls are fresh, delicious and they aren't stingy with the filling. The rice balls are also good and only $1 each! The curry is a huge portion and I really enjoyed the fish, which I selected as my protein. However the sauce is just okay. I wish it was a little more sweet or spicy and I also think they should cut their veggies into smaller pieces. But a few of my coworkers love the sauce so it's definitely worth a try. 

I'll be back soon. I can't wait to try their donburi and handmade mochi! No seating inside so plan to take it to go. Service is pretty fast and very friendly.
author: Alice J.

description: Surprisingly good! The Katsu bento box is good! The shining parts of this box are  the shrimp dumplings, the teriyaki meat and the large portion of rice. The shrimp tempura roll is very good as well. Huge plus, all of this is pre-made so your lunch break doesn't have to be shortened with cook time.
author: Alicia S.

description:
This is the same place as Ebisu: http://www.yelp.com/biz/ebisu-san-francisco-2 just with a new name and different ownership.

I work nearby and this has quickly ranked up among my favorite regular lunch spots in the Financial District / Downtown area.  Its grab-and-go format makes it easy to get in and get out.  There's several stations with lots of options - fresh rolls, salads, chicken teriyaki.  They even have spam musubi which made my heart skip a beat (if you've been to Hawaii you know).
author: Benjamin K.

description:
Handrolls? Yes
Mochi? Yes
Curry?! Yes
Bento? Yes
Vegetarian Bento? YYYYES!
Udon? Yes
Sushi? DAH!

I'm a fan!
author: Noir L.

description:
Solid lunch spot in the Union Sq/Financial District / SOMA borders. The food is good, but a bit pricey for what you get.

The donburi is usually my go to and it is a filling dish for your lunch time cravings.
author: Justin O.

description: Reliable spot for lunch, but the lines can get really long so you want to time it right. The people who work here are always happy and courteous and polite and I enjoy coming in. Lines move fast too because they're efficient. Will be in my weekly lunch rotation for the foreseeable future :)
author: Christina L.

description: It's Ebisu! Renamed! I can't tell the difference between this place and the last joint (meaning, I don't know if it's supposed to be a different restaurant in menu, theme, etc.). The shelves were moved around a bit, but there's the same arrangement of salads, sushi, bento boxes, hand rolls, and rice balls. Still good, don't get me wrong!
author: Bill H.

description:
Rice balls for $1 each! or spam musubi for $2 each! MUCH MUCH better than paying $3.75 each at Onigilly across the street.

I bought 3 rice balls today for a $3 spankin dollars (tuna & salmon). They use white rice and put seasoning in the rice... much more flavorful than Onigilly.

Haven't tried their bento boxes, but I love rice balls so this place is a win for me!
author: Nancie T.

description: I found a hair in the salmon bento, so I had to alert them.  This made my appetite drop for the other bentos, so I thought it'd be safer to buy a crab/shrimp tempura handroll and mango mochi instead.  These items were phenomenal, and I ate them across the street at a sit-down onigiri restaurant named Onigilly.  Ha.  The quality and taste of Tenmatsu's stuff were 10x better than the 3 rice balls I got at Onigilly.  So now I'm conflicted.  Clean, sit-down onigiri place vs. to-go onigiri and bento place.  I have to give Tenmatsu another try.  I'm pretty sure they're solid.  Mango and strawberry mochis there are reason alone to go.
author: Terry K.

description:
The place formally known as Ebisu is still a winner.

The fact is you still get some authentic tasting Japanese food quickly and deliciously.  They have a great selection of donburi that you can just grab and go.  You can also special order anything that you don't see already available.  The one issue I have with the rice bowls is that all the meat is stacked on the top and overall there is just too much rice.

They also have udon soup that you can order.  Udon with Enoki mushrooms!  Their Udon singlehandedly got me through last week when I was sick.  You have to order the soup and wait a few minutes but it is worth the wait.
author: Fay M.

description:
I used to go here when it was called Ebisu and gave it a good review.  My go to was the donburi bowls because it was filling at a good price.

Now they've removed at least half the rice, and prices are either the same or higher. It appears that they may have cut down on the other ingredients, but I'm not sure.  Everything is smaller.   Sigh, I no longer go here because I'm left hungry with $9+ out of my pocket.
author: Jon K.

description: They serve my favorite part of Japanese food. You can get bento box lunch for $12-15 dollars and have a lot of food. Very very tasty chicken teriyaki bowl for $8.50. I love this place. I think they are only open for lunch during the week. I could eat almost everything on their menu.
author: Joe H.

description:
Guh. I should just move in. 

I never went to Ebisu, so you won't get the 'ugh, why don't you just come baaaack with your mochi' wails. This place is legit. The food is solid, the staff is supernice, and the price is more than right for a FiDi lunch. 

The only thing I don't LOOOOOVE is their rice. Weird, but the texture was just not having it for me. That being said, I want to date their udon, so four stars it is.
author: Jessica S.

description: Absolutely the best japanese food I've had in my little corner of FIDI; it's not the absolute freshest and sometimes sits out, but it's one of the best options around for how fast it is. Really satisfies a japanese food craving, and the portions are really really big, so the price is worth it. As many have mentioned, the japanese gentleman who works there most of the time is SO cute - I would go just for him.
author: Ashley S.

description: The small japanese man who stands by the handroll stand is a real character. He is all smiles but I am certain he leads a secret life as a legendary sword maker.  The food here is mostly grab and go bento boxes of medium size catering to SF workers looking for convenient food that tastes good. It isn't a cheap food option so its not a place I would go all that often but its great if you have a craving for japanese homestyle food. I recommend the donburi and the other boxes with various marinated meats over rice.
author: Huy V.

description:
I was an avid fan of Ebisu, eating there several times per week.  I went in to what is now Tenmatsu today and asked what happened to Ebisu; I was told the owner sold the business along with all the recipes and that nothing would be changing.  False. 

I got my normal crab and avocado rolls and I was extremely disappointed.  Long gone are the days of real crab.  Instead, I received FAKE CRAB mixed with mayonnaise, just like a pre-made california roll from a grocery store.  

For the same price ($2), Tenmatsu is serving fake crab as a crab and avocado hand roll.  Total fail.  I will not be going back. The only reason they are getting two stars is because the people who work there are so nice.
author: Anne G.

description: I was curious when I walked across this store and saw so many people going in so I thought I'd take a peek from the doorway and got pulled in by on one of the folks working there - really welcoming atmosphere. After taking a look around and greeted by two others in there I thought I'd give them a try and ordered a ribeye teriyaki donburi and an ume onigiri. First impressions was that it was that the donburi was somewhat small for its price but the beef was really tender. I think the donburi itself can lighten up on the teriyaki sauce because the beef was drenched in it but, overall it was a good experience. I think 2 onigiri's can make a meal ($1.50/ea) but figured if I was at a store, why not try something they're more known for rather than just small things.
author: Judy C.

description: I am just on a roll right now with Japanese food (get it, roll? heh heh...). I saw another review on the chirashi bowl and just had to try it out. I got to the place around 1:20pm and got the last bowl left. Well damn, it didn't look very appetizing, was smaller than I thought, and tasted just okay. This place is definitely convenient and fast, but get there before 1pm so you get better picks.
author: Joy Z.

description: Tenmatsu has become my latest addiction for a quick workday lunch. I haven't tried the sushi yet (eating raw food that has been sitting around creeps me out), but the bento boxes, hand rolls and tofu donburi are really good. Get here around 2:00 and everything is 50% off!
author: Yum N.

description: A fast, no nonsense place where you can walk in, grab your box, pay, and go. I've gotten their bento boxes a few times, and the portions are a tad bit smaller than I'd like them to be and they really overdo the sauce. But the speed at which you can get your food somewhat compensates for this. Go here if you're in a hurry; otherwise, skip it.
author: Daylen Y.

description: No waits. Literally a grab and go. Lots of options that look very fresh and appetizing but on the pricey side for what doesn't look like a lot of food. Then again, sushi is deceptively filling.
author: Gee H.

description: Five stars mostly for the tasty vegetarian options here(mostly vegan!) from sushi to rice bowls to cold udon, there are SO many options to choose from!! I love how they change things up all the time. The guys here are friendly(one of them maybe too friendly haha) and there is never a long wait. Definitely one of my favorite lunch spots.
author: Angelina M.

description: This review is for the mochi only!  Under Ebisu, the mochi was damn good. Now, it's another story.  Went here today and picked up several different flavors of mochi. Luckily, I didn't get sick off this stuff; the green tea mango mochi was spoiled!  And the two other flavors were just not good. Even my 4 year old daughter tasted the difference. All the mochi had to be dumped. What a waste of money!
author: Steve L.

description:
This is not the same as ebisu. Please stop trying to say it is. The fish is not as fresh and the fresh fruit filled mochi's are not as amazing. I absolutely loved ebisu and I've tried this place twice now, hoping it would taste as good as ebisu. The spicy salmon handroll I had was fishy and the sashimi was sliced oddly and questionable...

I miss ebisu.
author: Amy S.

description: Their sushi rice is perfect and very flavorful. I recommend their salmon skin hand roll and string bean salad. Their miso soup is also the best I've ever had and is packed with veggies, tofu, and fish cake.
author: LoveFood W.

description: I'm very disappointed in Tenmatsu.  They try to serve the same meals as Ebjsu but it is apparent that the chef is not familiar with Japanese cooking.  The croquettes are made of only mashed potatoes with bits of carrots and the flavor is terrible.  The only upside is that it is bigger in size.
author: alex m.

description: Great lunch spot. I never went here when it was the previous company, but I can't complain about this one. The people are incredibly nice, it's super quick, and the food is delicious. I've had the udon (pork and veggie - i liked the pork one better), a few sushi plates, the handrolls, and one of the bento dishes. All were good, but it isn't the cheapest. You usually end up somewhere between $12 and $15 for lunch.
author: Sarah K.

description: Probably one of the more underrated lunch places on Kearny. Huge variety of options, super quick, cheap.
author: Lilian K.

description:
Grab and go place with great food for the price. I recommend the salmon teriyaki bowl (loaded with green and yellow onions). Huge piece of salmon and a ton of rice. I can also recommend the chicken udon. Their hand rolls (hamachi, spicy tuna, shrimp tempura) were also good too but kind of small. They are only $2. 

If you come after 2pm they discount everything left in the store 20%. 

Come before or after 12pm as the line gets long and the small place gets crowded.
author: Bobby D.

description: Tenmatsu is great for the immediately available rice bowl. I probably grab lunch here more than anywhere else at work.
author: Michael K.

description: Every so often during work the weather is extremely ugly and cloudy, Japanese curry sounds like a good meal to eat. THANKFULLY, Tenmatsu offers Japanese curry with various meats(fish katsu, beef, vege, pork katsu, etc) with white rice or brown rice. The curry is steaming hot(which is good), and packs a nice kick of spices(not too spicy). I usually get a mochi(they make it there so it is not the frozen types you can get at ranch 99), and the mochi comes with a piece of fresh fruit inside of it. I have tried the green tea mochi with mago and the strawberry mochi with redbean, which were both damn good. They also have a decent selection of drinks. I usually get the Sangaria MELON SODA....nice refreshing drink. Will be back again....
author: Mike Z.

description: I love this place! Food is good with friendly service. There's no seating, but you can take your food a half a block down to St Mary's Square.
author: Dean I.

description: Ready to go sushi and bento boxes. The potstickers were good, but their sushi is not fresh at all.
author: Karen H.

description: Perfect grab-n-go spot in the city for lunchtime! I've only tried their vegetarian combo sushi and it was really good for pre-made sushi. There were 2 different types of rolls for $10. I'm not exactly sure about the ingredients, I think one had avocado, some type of pickle, and another vegetable and the other one had tempura green beans, carrots and a few other vegetables. I loved that the two different rolls had such variety and it was pretty reasonably priced for 2 relatively large sushi rolls. The best part about this place is that it is SO QUICK! Everything is pre-made, so you just go into the small store and pick up whatever you please - all the labelling is really good and you can see all your different options before making a decision. I really like the concept of this restaurant and it's in a great location for grab-n-go! Don't be scared about the shady exterior, the food is actually pretty good!
author: Malika R.

description:
I have only tried the fish curry since it became Tenmatsu and I'd give it 2 stars.

The curry is not good.  Ebisu made good curry, but this curry had all potatoes (barely a veggie) and was watery.  Not really good flavor.  The fish tempura was fine, but what use to be good curry to buy is NOT A REPEAT.

We got there at 12:15pm and they were sold out of all the bento boxes except one I wasn't interested in.  

I did notice the $1 onnigilly, might consider getting it next time.
author: Lillian M.

description: I'm really happy with Tenmatsu. I was nervous about the switch from Ebisu, but the donburi bowls still taste the same to me. I'm really happy with the small additions to the menu, including musubi and spam musubi.
author: Greg M.

description: The staff is friendly. There's usually a long line at lunch but the line goes quickly.  I like the sushi here.  It's very decent for pre-packed "to-go" sushi.  I highly recommend the yellowtail hand rolls. One of my favorite lunch spots when I'm looking for something good and quick.
author: Tomoko S.

description: Very good grab and go Japanese food.  Very friendly service.  If you want brown rice with your order, you have to go early and ask for it.
author: Garrett H.

description: Great for grab-and-go. The sushi is just alright but works if you're really hungry and don't have much time :)
author: Cody W.
